the point is is that uh there's there's recently been this trend towards using non relational databases uh some people
are referring to it as the nosql movement and I think the reasons for that are that there are some
shortcomings in terms of the traditional rdbms in terms of both its ability to
scale out uh horizontally and also in terms of flexibility for developers working with uh within the relational uh
Paradigm and so we've seen a bunch different types of products that are trying to address this in the
non-relational space so uh there's things like key value stores which are have a pretty simplistic data model
basically put and get on a single key uh but that allows them to scale very well and and very easily and also to offer
pretty good performance and I think with mongodb the goal is to sort of bridge the gap between those sort of key value
stores which have this simple data model and something like an rdbms which has much more complicated data model and uh
is full of features and so with mongodb we're sort of trying to maintain the scalability and performance of the key

it stands more or less for binary Jon so uh I'm not a linguist I don't know if

can serialize to and from Bon and uh it's it's pretty much a seral
serialization of a super set of Json so it's Json plus we support some
additional types like uh a separate type for floating points than for integers

encodes it to this Bon format and sends it to the database and the cool thing is
that that's already a format that the database understands so it pretty much just takes that data and writes it right

yeah so um so certainly do um and and I think that's you know both an advantage
and a disadvantage so one thing that's interesting about data in mongodb is that the the notion of embedding
documents so um documents are what we call these these you know objects that
you're storing in the database which are more less Json like so in Ruby it's a hash in Python it's a dictionary in
JavaScript it's a map or in Java it's a map uh in JavaScript it's an object whatever it is but um so it's not just a
first level thing though so in a relational database if you were working on a a Blog for example you'd probably
have a table for posts and a table for comments and and when you wanted to get
a post and its comments to display on a page you'd do a join and in something
like mongodb where you can store embedded documents one good way to represent that relationship would be to
actually take those comment documents and actually embed them right within the post itself um and so that allows you to
go ahead and get a post with all of its comments and it's all coming from the same place and it's all a single
document and so you're going to see significant performance increases but doing that versus doing a join um and
and in some cases it can also be easier to work with to use these embedded documents so it does create uh I think
it does create some I don't I don't think problems is the right word but there there's certainly some things you
have to think about which is when does it make sense to embed documents versus referencing other documents in a
different collection and and doing more like like a join type thing um and there are certainly cases where each makes
sense so there are some some different sets of things you need to think about in terms of designing your uh your
schema as it is or as you might call it you know early
on when I was working with I found myself um developing I guess wider schemas than
than deep schemas based on whether or not I needed to return a particular type as a top level object itself but with

um coming up with the model that we're going to use for map reduce and then there's been some you know making sure

uh you wouldn't be doing a map reduce job as a simple query you know that
you're using to generate a response to a page like instantaneous in real time uh
so the way it is right now it would be more of like U every couple minutes do a map reduce job generate some results and
then use those results to to uh respond to later queries so um that's been the
model that we're working with now and so I think some of the difficulties are are getting map reduce right in a sharded

really really nice and this is you know we specify the key and then a hash of values and then we'll do one fire and
forget update or insert and then the other are the modifier operations set
ink push push all um how did those come about as far as features do you guys
just develop to scratch your own itch or how do features get I guess developed
into the uh the framework yeah so upsert and and the update modifier so I'll I'll introduce those a little bit more for
people who might not be familiar with them but uh but mongodb supports an update operation and one option when you
do an update is to do an upsert which says if you can't find a document to update then go ahead and create this new
document instead and like you said that that can be really nice for doing a fire fire and forget insert or update and
then the other thing that you mentioned are these Atomic operators so we support a bunch of different atom Atomic
operators for updates like increment uh set append to an array a bunch of
different things and those can be really nice too so for doing something like real-time analytics if you have some
document and you want to increment a counter you can just send a single update operation you don't need to go
get the document modify and save it back um and you can do that increment like
that and and so those are very useful as well and allow for uh some good performance benefits and those have been
